results.title: Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome
results.credit_line: Courtesy Kennedy Miller Mitchell Films Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979-85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.
results.description:
Taking an unexpected direction from the genre Miller established with his highly influential previous films, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome finds our reluctant hero coming face-to-face with the feudal Aunty Entity (Tina Turner), who lords over Bartertown and the deadly battle arena, Thunderdome.

Less emphasis on car chases and more on the brutal tribal world Aunty Entity and her minions reign over, the film sees Max leading a band of feral orphans to freedom. Never fear though, Beyond Thunderdome still bristles with mind-boggling retro-fitted cars, hair-raising stunt work, bizarre costumes and intricate world building to make this third entry into the series as white-knuckled as its predecessors.
description_for_label:
Taking an unexpected direction from the genre Miller established with his highly influential previous films, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome finds our reluctant hero coming face-to-face with the feudal Aunty Entity (Tina Turner), who lords over Bartertown and the deadly battle arena, Thunderdome.

Less emphasis on car chases and more on the brutal tribal world Aunty Entity and her minions reign over, the film sees Max leading a band of feral orphans to freedom. Never fear though, Beyond Thunderdome still bristles with mind-boggling retro-fitted cars, hair-raising stunt work, bizarre costumes and intricate world building to make this third entry into the series as white-knuckled as its predecessors.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Kennedy Miller Mitchell Films Pty Ltd

results.title: Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979-85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.
results.description:
Director George Miller didn’t waste anytime giving cinemagoers everything they loved from the original Mad Max and more! After the deaths of his wife and child, Max (Mel Gibson) wanders the post-apocalyptic Australian outback, nomadically navigating a landscape descended into tribal warfare. The bare minimal plot was (mostly) abandoned for spectacular high speed chases that make it a must see for all action fans.

Miller matched then quickly exceeded expectations with this breakneck sequel to the genre original. The films startling use of the arid outback and perverse costuming again set the benchmark for other genre films, especially in the US and Europe where it spawned many imitations and is still referenced to this day in film, music video and fashion. Again Miller ups the ante with the white-knuckled practical stunts which he would go on to perfect in the award-winning Mad Max: Fury Road.
description_for_label:
Director George Miller didn’t waste anytime giving cinemagoers everything they loved from the original Mad Max and more! After the deaths of his wife and child, Max (Mel Gibson) wanders the post-apocalyptic Australian outback, nomadically navigating a landscape descended into tribal warfare. The bare minimal plot was (mostly) abandoned for spectacular high speed chases that make it a must see for all action fans.

Miller matched then quickly exceeded expectations with this breakneck sequel to the genre original. The films startling use of the arid outback and perverse costuming again set the benchmark for other genre films, especially in the US and Europe where it spawned many imitations and is still referenced to this day in film, music video and fashion. Again Miller ups the ante with the white-knuckled practical stunts which he would go on to perfect in the award-winning Mad Max: Fury Road.

results.title: How to Sell to Australia
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

constellations_primary.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_primary.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million views on YouTube with the campaign’s song known globally, having charted on iTunes in 28 countries. While light-hearted, at its core the hugely successful commercial carries a serious message: Be Safe Around Trains.

results.description: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.
description_for_label: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.

results.title: Electric sound
results.brief_description: The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction.

constellations_primary.name: Electric Sound Supercut: composers and their distinctive other worlds
constellations_primary.description: Electric sound is commonly associated with science fiction narratives for its auditory oddness, which has symbolised other worldly environments, the unconscious and the 1980s.

results.description: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.
description_for_label: Specific types of movies have a specific sound. Overtime, these associations inevitably become subconscious. The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction, while husband and wife composers Bebe and Louis Barron are credited with creating the first fully realised electronic film score for 50s cult classic Forbidden Planet (1956). From deploying unconventional instruments to early looping and splicing techniques, the legacy of electric sound can still be found today in the works of composers like Danny Elfman.

images.caption: The Day the Earth Stood Still (still)
images.credit_line: A still from The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)

results.title: Arrival of sound
results.brief_description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. Actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the ‘Talkie Terror’, but when Don Juan and The Jazz Singer debuted, there was no turning back.

constellations_primary.name: Significant sounds
constellations_primary.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

results.description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.
description_for_label: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.

results.title: Into a World of Colour
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of cinema, filmmakers experimented with colour and sound by hand-tinting frames and providing orchestral accompaniments. But it wasn’t until the early 20th century that ‘talkies’ truly changed the industry and glorious Technicolor ushered in the first golden age of cinema.

constellations_primary.name: Into a World of Colour
constellations_primary.description: Filmmakers have been using colour as a method of storytelling since the first moving pictures. Colour can be used to signify emotion, intensify drama or to create a strong visual aesthetic.
